Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Quantifying Fluorescent Probe Dynamics in FRET Experiments by Combining Single-Molecule and Bulk Spectroscopies with Molecular Dynamics and Quantum Mechanics Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Brent Kruger and his group at Hope College seek to improve the understanding and therefore the capabilities of fluorescence-detected resonance energy transfer (FRET), a powerful method for characterizing the structure and dynamics of biologically important molecules like proteins and nucleic acids. As test systems, several biologically important yet relatively simple DNA and RNA sequences based on the hairpin ribozyme will be tagged with a series of fluorescent probes to examine the impact of probe molecule and chemical attachment method on FRET results. Both fluorescence measurements and sophisticated computational modeling will be used to provide detailed understanding of structural dynamics. Because FRET is a widely-used technique in chemistry, biology, and biophysics, the results of this work will positively impact a large community of researchers.

The research will provide effective research training experiences for the students involved. Through programs already in place at Hope College, these will include two-year-college and local high school students in addition to Hope College undergraduates. Over the period of the grant, four to five students will be engaged in research each summer including at least one underrepresented minority student. In addition, an outreach program will bring 12 high school teachers to Hope's campus each summer to learn molecular modeling techniques and to develop lessons for their classrooms that meet state and national education standards. Assessment of the students who have benefitted from these lessons over the past two years shows that 40% of students report an increased interest in attending college and 29% report an increased interest in pursuing a STEM career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported a variety of projects over its lifetime.  The primary intellectual merit was the creation of parameters describing six common fluorescent proteins (FPs) for use in molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. A protein of interest can be “tagged” genetically with one of these FPs, such that when made by the cell, the protein and FP are a single unit, making the protein easy to identify. Scientists in many fields use FPs to identify when during the life of a cell the protein of interest is generated and where it moves within individual cells or within the organism under study. In the past two decades FPs have become incredibly important across a huge swath of studies in biology, chemistry, physics and other fields. MD simulations are used to understand, from an atomic-level perspective, how the structures of proteins lead to their functions and how proteins and nucleic acids interact with each other both during normal function and during disease. While a number of studies using MD to describe fluorescent proteins have been executed, researchers have either left out the fluorescent part of the FP or have developed ad hoc descriptions that are inconsistent from study to study. Our work provides a uniform, modular framework to describe fluorescent proteins that can be consistently employed by all researchers. It is built into, and freely available through, the popular MD software package AMBER. Because it is modular, it is also easily extended to other fluorescent proteins by us or by other researchers.

In addition to the easy availability of the MD parameters mentioned above, the broader impacts include two primary areas. First, because this research is centered at a liberal arts college, there are no graduate students involved, only undergraduate (and a few high school) students. These students are executing authentic research providing them with exceptional training for careers in STEM, whether they intend those careers to begin directly after their undergraduate degrees, or they intend to pursue graduate or professional schools. Second, this award included an outreach effort targeting high school teachers.  Over the course of the grant, 50 high school teachers lived at Hope College for one week during the summer and each developed a lesson to fit their own curriculum that incorporated the kinds of molecular modeling tools used by researchers worldwide. These teachers brought the lessons back to their schools and used them to improve their students’ understanding of the molecular nature of matter and role of three-dimensional shape and structure of molecules. These students, who include significant numbers of students on free/reduced lunch plans (40%) as well as underrepresented minorities (20%), learned to use professional molecular modeling software and executed, as a group, more than 15,000 quantum mechanics calculations. Through assessments, these students consistently self-reported an increased desire to attend college (39%) and to pursue careers in science (29%) and computing (25%).
